title: Ronnie O'Sullivan in latest dig at World Snooker over wonky rests
text:
Ronnie O’Sullivan is rarely far from making a complaint about something (Picture: Getty Images)

It is rare indeed that Ronnie O’Sullivan misses an opportunity to have a pop at World Snooker, and when he was lumbered with a wonky rest on Wednesday, he was given the perfect opportunity.

The Rocket was en route to a narrow 4-3 victory over Yuan Sijun in the English Open second round when he went to use the rest, only to see that it wasn’t straight.

The world number two pointed it out to the referee, but instead of waiting for a replacement rest, he played the shot anyway and missed.

O’Sullivan insisted he would rather have just got one with the game, as he did, because there was unlikely to be a better piece of equipment in the arena.

‘They probably didn’t have it in the budget to get some decent rests,’ the Rocket told Eurosport. ‘I just wanted one that was straight.

‘The ref wanted to send his mate out and I thought, “oh come on mate, I’m not that bothered” just play the shot. I’d rather miss it than have him walking around the building eight times to find something.

‘They probably haven’t got one anyway.’

It has been a bizarrely eventful tournament for O’Sullivan with rests after he dropped one on the floor during his first round win over Jamie O’Neill, played a shot, then kicked it under the table.

Ronnie described that as ‘quite a professional thing to do’ in order to keep the game going, but it was hardly standard practice for a televised event.

It wouldn't be a @ronnieo147 match without a bonkers moment, would it? Here's his "professional" way of moving the rest 😂 🎱 Watch the #EnglishOpen LIVE:

📺 – Eurosport 1

📱💻🖥 – Eurosport Player: https://t.co/0Fa7uXMVB9 pic.twitter.com/I6OfroOYFa — Eurosport UK (@Eurosport_UK) October 14, 2019

The criticism of the rest on Wednesday was the latest blast for World Snooker from the five-time world champion this week, after he also complained about having to play in Crawley and about taking on much lower-ranked opponents in the early rounds.

World Snooker chairman Barry Hearn has not taken this lying down, calling the Rocket ‘deadly dull’ and asking for ‘enough of all this nonsense.’

Hopefully there will be no more issues with the equipment at the K2 Leisure Centre in Crawley as O’Sullivan plays his third round match at the English Open on Thursday afternoon against Hossein Vafaei.
